The word charity has lost its original noble signification ; and men, nominally Christiane, go 011 hating each other, as if Christ had never taught and never died.

Nor could the result under the circumstances have been otherwise. Conduct results from motives3 motives depend on notions and conceptions. All evil, when perceived and understood, is hateful. As long as our psychological notions are so incomplete that we can conceive a being, with will free from coercion, and with just perceptione of good and evil, deliberately choosing the evil, we must view such a being as hateful. If such a being could exist (which is impossible) he would be consciously an author of

ful is a contradiction in terms3 the very least we could desire for such a being would be annihilation. The new moral law, then, which Christianity pro· claimed has never yet been carried out, because the grounds on which it rested have never yet been dis- tinctly and generally perceived, The law of the heart is to follow the highest good in sight, and to feel hatred and aversion for the bad. As long there· fore as, through ignorance of psychology, the exist· ence of beings is considered possible who, being altogether free and independent of circumstances, could deliberately prefer the bad, such beings must excite in the human heart the sentiment of hatred.
